metadata.title: Crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein RNA binding domain 1 reveals potential unique drug targeting sites

abstract.text: The outbreak of coronavirus disease in China caused by SARS-CoV-2 virus 24 continually lead to worldwide human infections and deaths. It is currently no specific viral protein 25

targeted therapeutics yet. Viral nucleocapsid protein is a potential antiviral drug target, serving 26 multiple critical functions during the viral life cycle. However, the structural information of SARS-27

CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein is yet to be clear. Herein, we have determined the 2.7 Å crystal 28 structure of the N-terminal RNA binding domain of SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein. 29 Although overall structure is similar with other reported coronavirus nucleocapsid protein N-30 terminal domain, the surface electrostatic potential characteristics between them are distinct. 31 Further comparison with mild virus type HCoV-OC43 equivalent domain demonstrates a unique 32 potential RNA binding pocket alongside the b-sheet core. Complemented by in vitro binding 33 studies, our data provide several atomic resolution features of SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid 34 protein N-terminal domain, guiding the design of novel antiviral agents specific targeting to 35 SARS-CoV-2. 36

body_text.text: translates into two polyproteins (pp1a and pp1ab) and encodes most of the non-structural 50 proteins (nsp). The rest parts of virus genome encode accessory proteins and four essential 51 structural proteins, including spike (S) glycoprotein, small envelope (E) protein, matrix (M) 52 protein, and nucleocapsid (N) protein 1, 2 . Current antiviral drugs developed to treat coronavirus 53 (CoV) infections primarily target S protein, the 3C-like (3CL) and papain-like (PLP) proteases 3, 4 . 54

Because mutant viruses in the S protein is prone to escape the targeted therapeutic with 55 different host-cell receptor binding patterns 4 , as well as antibody-dependent enhancement 56 (ADE) effects of S protein antibodies are found in MERS coronavirus 5 , there are several limitations 57 on targeting S protein for antiviral approaches. Antiviral protease inhibitors may nonspecifically 58 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.06.977876 doi: bioRxiv preprint act on the cellular homologous protease, resulting in host cell toxicity and severe side effects. 59 Therefore, novel antiviral strategies are needed to combat acute respiratory infections caused 60 by this novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2. 61

The CoV N protein is a multifunctional RNA-binding protein necessary for viral RNA 62 transcription and replication. It plays many pivotal roles in forming helical ribonucleoproteins 63 during packaging the RNA genome, regulating viral RNA synthesis during replication, 64 transcription and modulating infected cell metabolism [6] [7] [8] . The primary functions of N protein are 65 binding to the viral RNA genome, and packing them into a long helical nucleocapsid structure 66 or ribonucleoprotein (RNP) complex 9,10 . In vitro and in vivo experiments revealed that N protein 67 bound to leader RNA, and was critical for maintaining highly ordered RNA conformation suitable 68 for replicating, and transcribing the viral genome 7,11 . More studies implicated that N protein 69 regulated host-pathogen interactions, such as actin reorganization, host cell cycle progression, 70 and apoptosis [12] [13] [14] . The N protein is also a highly immunogenic and abundantly expressed protein 71 during infection, capable of inducing protective immune responses against SARS-CoV and 72 At present work, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid N-terminal 87 domain (termed as SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD), as a model for understanding the molecular 88 interactions that govern SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD binding to ribonucleotides. Compared with other 89 solved CoVs N-NTD, we characterized the specificity surface electrostatic potential features of 90 SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD. Additionally, we further demonstrated the unique RNA binding site 91 characteristics. Our findings will aid in the development of new drugs that interfere with viral N 92 protein and viral replication in SARS-CoV-2, and highly related virus SARS-CoV. 93

Briefly, 47-173 residues of SARS-CoV-2 N 152 protein were constructed, expressed and purified as described protocol (Materials and Methods). 153
body_text.section: Sequence features of SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein 132

body_text.text: The structure of SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD was determined by molecular replacement using the 154 SARS-CoV N-NTD structure (PDB:2OG3) as the search model 24 . The final structure was refined 155 to R-factor and R-free values of 0.26 and 0.29, respectively. The complete statistics for data 156 collection, phasing and refinement are presented in Table 1 . Unlike to SARS-CoV N-NTD crystals 157 packing modes (monoclinic form at 2OFZ, cubic form at 2OG3) 24 , SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD crystal 158
body_text.section: Sequence features of SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein 132

body_text.text: shows orthorhombic crystal packing form with four N-NTD monomers in one asymmetry unit 159 ( Fig. 2A) . Although lacks of evidence for real RNP organization in the mature virions, the 160 differences in the crystal packing patterns may implicate other potential contacts in SARS-CoV-161 2 RNP formation process. All four monomers in one asymmetric unit of the SARS-CoV-2 N-162 NTD crystal structure shared similar right-handed (loops)-(b-sheet core)-(loops) sandwiched 163 structure, as conserved among the CoVs N-NTD (Fig. 2B) . The b-sheet core is consisted of five 164 antiparallel b-strands with a single short 310 helix just before strand b2, and a protruding b-165 hairpin between strands b2 and b5. The b-hairpin is functionally important for CoV N-NTD, 166 implicated in mutational analysis of amino acid residues for RNA binding 29 (Fig. 2C) . The SARS-167
body_text.section: Sequence features of SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein 132

body_text.text: CoV-2 N-NTD is enriched in aromatic and basic residues, folding into a hand shape resembles 168 with basic fingers that extend far beyond the b-sheet core, a basic palm, and an acidic wrist (Fig.  169   2D) . 170

body_text.text: To obtain more specific information, we first mapped the conserved residues between SARS-172
body_text.section: Comparison of SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD with related viral N-NTD structures 171

body_text.text: CoV-2 N-NTD with SARS-CoV N-NTD, MERS-CoV N-NTD, HCoV-OC443 N-NTD, respectively 173 ( Fig 3A) . The most conserved residues distribute on the basic palm region (Fig. 3A, blue and  174 green region), while the less conserved residues locate in basic fingers and acidic wrist region 175 The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.06.977876 doi: bioRxiv preprint SARS-CoV-2 one (Fig. 4A) . The N-terminal tail movement contributed to the change of N-NTD 213 surface charge distribution, at which nucleotide binding cavity became easier to accessible in 214 SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD ( Fig. 4B and C) . The second difference is on phosphate group binding site, 215 which SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD have larger sidechain residues (55 TA 56) compared with HCoV-216 OC43 N-NTD equivalents (67 SG 68) (Fig. 4D) . Structural superimposition suggested additional 217 polar properties of Thr 55 and Ala 56 in SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD may increase the steric clash with 218 ribonucleotide phosphate moiety ( Fig. 4E and F) . The third difference is on the edge of 219 nitrogenous base recognized hydrophobic pocket, where SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD had Arg 89 220 residues compared with HCoV-OC43 N-NTD Tyr 102 equivalents (Fig. 4G) . The change of these 221 residues sidechain may lead to dramatic decreasing of non-polar properties and increasing of 222 polar properties in the nitrogenous base binding site ( Fig. 4H and I) . To evaluate these different 223 observations in our structure, Surface plasmon resonance (SPR) analysis experiments were next 224 performed to assess the binding affinity between SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD with all four kinds of 225 ribonucleotide AMP/UMP/CMP/GMP. Intriguingly, all ribonucleoside 5'-monophosphate, 226 excepted for GMP (KD value is 8 mM), shown little binding signals in assays (Fig. S4) . Taken 227 together, the above results suggested a potential distinct RNA binding patterns between SARS-228

body_text.text: Structure-based drug discovery has been shown to be an advance approach for the 231 development of new therapeutics. Many ongoing studies are developed to treat COVID-19 232 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

The copyright holder for this preprint (which was not peer-reviewed) is the . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.06.977876 doi: bioRxiv preprint primarily targeting the spike protein, viral proteases (3C-like protease and papain-like protease). 233

However, there is little effective targeted therapeutic currently. Recent studies demonstrated 234 that N proteins will be a good drug-targeting candidate in other CoVs since they process several 235 critical functions, such as RNA genomic packing, viral transcription and assembly, in the 236 infectious cell 10 . However, the molecular basis of SARS-CoV-2 N protein is yet to be elucidated. 237

Here, we present the 2.7 Å crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 N protein N-terminal domain, 238 revealing the specific surface charge distributions which may facilitate drug discovery specifically 239 to SARS-CoV-2 N protein ribonucleotide binding domain.

FIGREF0.text: outbreak of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a new emerging human 41 infectious disease caused by a novel coronavirus (severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 42 2, SARS-CoV-2, previously known as 2019-nCoV). As of 28 February 2020, a cumulative total of 43 78,961 COVID-19 cases were confirmed with 2791 deaths in China. The emerged global 44 epidemic spread rapidly with 4691 confirmed cases and 67 deaths across 51 countries outside 45 of China (COVID-19 situation Report WHO, 28 Feb 2020). Despite remarkable efforts on 46 containing spread of the virus, there is no specific targeted therapeutic currently. 47 SARS-CoV-2 is a betacoronavirus with single-stranded RNA genomes, like MERS-CoV and 48 SARS-CoV. The first two-thirds of viral 30kb RNA genome, mainly named as ORF1a/b region, 49

FIGREF1.text: Ulp1 protease digestion for tag removal, SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD (41-174) proteins were further 103 purified via size-exclusion chromatography (with buffer consisting of 20 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.0), 104 150 mM sodium chloride, 1 mM dithiothreitol), and then concentrated by ultrafiltration to a final 105 concentration of 22 mg/mL. 106 Crystallization and data collection Crystals were grown by the sitting drop method with 0.3ul 107 protein(22 mg/mL) mixed with 0.6 μL and 0.3 μL well solution using Mosquito crystallization 108 robot and after 3 days initial crystallization was performed under 16 °C under 20 mM sodium 109 acetate, 100 mM sodium cacodylate (pH 6.5), 26 % PEG8000 conditions. Crystals were frozen in 110 liquid nitrogen in reservoir solution supplemented with 15 % glycerol (v/v) as a cryoprotectant. 111 X-ray diffraction data were collected at the South China Sea Institute of Oceanology, Chinese 112

FIGREF2.text: NHS. After the injection of 30 μg/mL protein in 10 mM 119 sodium acetate (pH 5.5) for three times to immobilize on one of channels of the CM5 chip up 120 to ∼5,800 response units, 10 μL of 1 M ethanolamine (pH 8.0) was used for blocking the 121 remaining activated groups. Each of the analytes (AMP, GMP, UMP, CMP) were dissolve in PBS 122 (pH 7.4, 0.05 % NP-20) and flowed through the chip surface at flow rate of 30 μL/min at 25 °C. 123 30 μL analytes were injected for affinity analysis with 60 s dissociation time. To understanding 124 dose dependent affinity of analytes and SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD, we tested nine dilutions of 125 analytes from 0.15625 mM to 10 mM. A blank flow channel was used as a reference channel to 126 correct the bulk refractive index by subtracting the response signal of the reference channel 127 from the signals of protein immobilized cells. The equilibrium constant (KD) for analytes binding 128

FIGREF3.text: encoding region are conserved among the known NCBI 103 genome datasets. Only 137 a few variations (S194L in virus strain Foshan/20SF207/2020, K249I in virus strain Wuhan/IVDC-138 HB-envF13-21/2020, P344S in virus strain Guangzhou/20SF206/2020) in N protein are found in 139 public genomic epidemiology. An overall domain architecture of N protein among four 140 coronaviruses (SARS-CoV-2, SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV and HCoV-OC43) are shown in Figure 1B, 141 which indicates that SARS-CoV-2 shares typical characteristics with other coronaviruses. Zoom 142into the completed genomic sequence of SARS-CoV-2 N protein encoding region, we find that 143 the sequence identities between SARS-CoV-2 with SARS-CoV, MERS-CoV, and HCoV-OC43 144 are 89.74%, 48.59%, 35.62%, respectively(Fig. S1)38,39 . Since full-length SARS-CoV-2 N protein 145 aggregated status were found in our expression and purification studies(Fig. S2), as well as 146 previous reported data on other coronavirus nucleocapsid protein, we next investigate the 147 structural studies on N-terminal region of SARS-CoV-2 N protein (termed as SARS-CoV-

FIGREF4.text: Fig. 3A, pink and red region). The available CoVs N-NTD crystal structures allowed us to 176 compare the electrostatic potential on the surface. As shown in Fig. 3B, although CoV N-NTDs 177 all adapted similar overall organizations, the surface charge distribution patterns are different. 178 Consisting with our observations, previous modeling of related coronaviral N-NTDs also shown 179 markedly differ in surface charge distributions 24 . Superimposition of SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD with 180 three kinds of CoVs N-NTD are shown in Fig. 3C. Compared with SARS-CoV N-NTD, SARS-181 CoV-2 N-NTD show a 2.1 Å movement in the b-hairpin region forward to nucleotide binding 182 site (Fig. 3C, left panel). While compared with MERS-CoV N-NTD, SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD show a 183 less extended b-hairpin region, and a distinct relax N-treminal tail (Fig. 3C, middle panel). In 184 consistently, SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD show a distinct relax N-treminal tail, and a 2 Å movement in 185 the b-hairpin region backward to the opposite side of nucleotide binding site when the structure 186 is compared with HCoV-OC43 N-NTD (Fig. 3C, right panel). These differences dramatically 187 change the surface characterizations of the protein, may result in the RNA-binding cleft being 188 adaptive to its own RNA genome. 189 A potential unique drug target pocket in SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD 190 Although there are several CoV N-NTDs structures have been solved, the structural basis for 191 -NTD between SARS-CoV-2 with HCoV-OC43 are distinct, we next explored the differences 194 of RNA binding mechanistic basis with superimposition analysis. Previous studies had shown 195 that, HCoV-OC43 N-NTD contained Adenosine monophosphate (AMP)/ uridine 196 monophosphate (UMP)/ cytosine monophosphate (CMP)/ guanosine monophosphate (GMP) 197 binding site alongside the middle two b strands of its b-sheets core 40 . In the complex structure 198 of HCoV-OC43 N-NTD with ribonucleotides, the phosphate group was bound by Arg 122 and 199 Gly 68 via ionic interactions, the pentose sugar ribose 2'-hydroxyl group was recognized by 200 Ser 64 and Arg164, the nitrogenous base inserted into a hydrophobic pocket consisting of Phe 201 57, Pro61, Tyr 63, Tyr102, Tyr 124, and Tyr 126, mainly interacted with Tyr 124 via p-p stacking 202 forces(Fig. S3). It is proposed that this ribonucleotide binding mechanism are essential for all 203 coronavirus N proteins, applying to develop CoV N-NTD-target agents. 204To obtain the structure information of SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD ribonucleotide binding site, we 205 make a superimposition of SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD with HCoV-OC43 N-NTD-AMP complex. As 206 expectedly, the root mean square deviation (RMSD) between these two structure coordinates 207 are 1.4 Å over 136 superimposed Ca atoms. However, a number of difference around the 208 ribonucleotide binding site were shown as superimposition of SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD with HCoV-209 OC43 N-NTD. The major difference is N-terminal tail of N-NTD with sequence variation (SARS-210CoV-2: 48 NNTA 51 versus HCoV-OC43: 60 VPYY 63). In HCoV-OC43 N-NTD, the tail folded 211 up to compose a nitrogenous base binding channel, whereas this region extended outward in 212 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission.

FIGREF5.text: 240 On the structural basis of SARS-CoV-2 N-NTD, several residues in the ribonucleotide binding 241 domain were found to distinctly recognize the CoV RNA substrates. The N-terminal tail residues 242 (Asn 48, Asn 49, Thr 50, and Ala 51) is more flexible and extended outward compared with 243 equivalent residues in HCoV-OC43 N-NTD, possibly opening up the binding pocket into fitting 244 with viral RNA genomic high order structure. Residues Arg 89, instead of HCoV-OC43 N-NTD 245 Tyr 102, may contribute to guanosine base recognition despite the overall ribonucleotide 246 binding may be excluded by residues Thr 55 and Ala 56 in the phosphate moiety recognition 247 site. 248 Up to date, seven coronaviruses have been identified as human-susceptible virus, among which 249 HCoV-229E, HCoV-NL63, HCoV-HKU1 and HCoV-OC43 with low pathogenicity cause mild 250 respiratory symptoms similar to common cold, whereas the other three betacoronaviruses, 251 SARS-CoV-2, SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV lead to severe and potential fatal respiratory tract 252 Previous study reported the structural basis of HCoV-OC43 N-NTD with AMP, 253 GMP, UMP, CMP and a virtual screening-base compound PJ34. However, our data suggested 254 that SARS-CoV-2 employed a unique pattern for binding RNA with atomic resolution 255 information. The structure not only help us to understand the RNA-binding mechanisms 256 between severe infectious coronavirus with mild infectious one, but also guide the design of 257 novel antiviral agents specific targeting to SARS-CoV-2. 258 Acknowledgments 259 We thank for Guangdong Medical Laboratory Animal Center for providing the N-protein 260 encoding gene plasmids, Dr. Yongzhi Lu from Guangzhou Institutes of Biomedicine and Health 261 (Chinese Academy of Sciences) for the initial crystals X-ray diffraction screening, supports from 262 Dr. Xuan Ma of South China Sea Institute of Oceanology (Chinese Academy of Sciences) for 263 home source X-ray diffraction facility. This work was supported by National Natural Science 264 Foundation of China (31770801) and Special Fund for Scientific and Technological Innovation 265 Strategy of Guangdong Province of China (2018B030306029, 2017A030313145) to S.C. 266

FIGREF6.text: Sequence features of SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein 272 Figure legend: A. The complete whole genomic features of SARS-CoV-2 isolate Wuhan-Hu-1 273 (Genebank: MN908947). UTR: untranslated region; orf/ORF: open reading frame; TRS: 274 transcriptional regulatory sequences; S: spike glycoprotein encoding region; E: envelope protein 275 encoding region; M: membrane protein encoding region; N: nucleocapsid protein encoding 276 region. The figure is illustrated by SnapGene Viewer; B. Domain architectures of coronavirus 277 nucleocapsid protein. NTD: N-terminal RNA-binding domain; CTD: C-terminal dimerization 278 domain; C. TABREF0.text: The common domain architectures of coronavirus N protein are consisting of three distinct but 74 highly conserved parts: An N-terminal RNA-binding domain (NTD), a C-terminal dimerization 75 domain (CTD), and intrinsically disordered central Ser/Arg (SR)-rich linker. Previous studies have 76 revealed that the NTD are responsible for RNA binding, CTD for oligomerization, and (SR)-rich 77 author/funder. All rights reserved. No reuse allowed without permission. end of the viral RNA genome, possibly through electrostatic interactions. Additionally, several 81 critical residues have been identified for RNA binding and virus infectivity in the N-terminal 82 However, the structural and mechanistic basis for newly 83 emerged novel SARS-CoV-2 N protein remain largely unknown. Understanding these aspects 84 should facilitate the discovery of agents that specifically block the coronavirus replication, 85
